questions.text: Tyrosinosis is caused due to deficiency of which enzyme?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase There are 3 Types of Tyrosinemia Disease Enzyme deficient / deficiency features Tyrosinemia type I or Tyrosinosis/ Hepatic renal Tyrosinemia/ Hereditary Tyrosinemia Fumaryl Aceto Acetate Hydrolase Most common Tyrosinemia Type II or Richner Hanhart Syndrome aka oculocutaneous Tyrosinemia Tyrosine Transaminase Eyes and skin are involved. Tyrosinemia Type III or Neonatal Tyrosinemia Complete deficiency of PHPP (Para Hydroxy - Phenyl Pyruvate) Hydroxylase Partial deficiency, of PHPP Hydroxylase, is called Hawkinson Urea

questions.text: Which steps are correct for Sarcosine synthesis from serine:

options.label: A
options.text: Serine undergoes decarboxylation to ethanolamine by the decarboxylase enzyme

options.label: B
options.text: Methylation of ethanolamine forms trimethyl ethanolamine called choline

options.label: C
options.text: Choline is converted into betaine by the enzyme choline dehydrogenase

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Serine undergoes decarboxylation to ethanolamine by the decarboxylase enzyme and by a pyridoxal phosphate coenzyme. The methylation of ethanol amine forms trimethyl ethanol amine called choline. The choline is converted into acetylcholine via choline acetyltransferase (See fig)

questions.text: Glycine is the simplest amino acid. It can be metabolically converted into all of the following compounds in the body except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cysteine Cysteine is the sulfur-containing non-essential amino acid. It is produced in the body from serine. Serine+ Homocysteine →Cysteine+ Homoserine

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option: A. Creatine is produced in the body from glycine, arginine, and methionine amino acids Option: B. The glycine condenses with succinyl CoA in the presence of the enzyme ALA synthase and forms delta amino levulinic acid (ALA). The ALA synthase is the key enzyme in heme synthesis. Option: C. Glycine molecule contributes to C4, C5 and N7 in purine nitrogenous bases

questions.text: An infant was taken to the hospital with symptoms of vomiting, blood in stool, loss of weight, and loss of appetite. After a thorough examination, the infant was diagnosed with intellectual disability and neurological dysfunctions. It was declared neonatal tyrosinemia. Select the incorrect statement?

options.label: A
options.text: Reported in premature infants. Very few cases have been cited in the literature

options.label: B
options.text: Deficiency of the enzyme 4-hydroxy phenyl pyruvate dioxygenase

options.label: C
options.text: Serum levels of tyrosine are elevated

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option: A. Few cases of neonatal tyrosinemia are found in the It is seen in premature infants. Option: B. 4-hydroxy phenyl pyruvate dioxygenase catalyzes the conversion of 4-hydroxy phenyl pyruvate into Homogentisic acid in tyrosine catabolism. Its deficiency results in neonatal tyrosinemia which is also directly linked to alkaptonuria. Option: C. Serum levels of tyrosine are elevated due to incomplete breakdown of tyrosine

questions.text: A 4-year-old child was found to have developmental delays and severe mental retardation. His blood showed high levels of phenylalanine and phenylpyruvate. The child was given a low-phenylalanine diet which did not improve his condition. Keeping this information in mind, which one of the following conversions is not occurring properly in this child?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tyrosine to dopamine The child has non-classical PKU , which is due to a defect in the biosynthesis of tetrahydrobiopterin. Tetrahydrobiopterin is required for ring hydroxylation reactions, such as the conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine, tyrosine to DOPA , and tryptophan to serotonin. However, tetrahydrobiopterin is not required for the conversion of DOPA to melanin, serotonin to melatonin, and norepinephrine to epinephrine, which is a methylation reaction. A deficiency of tetrahydrobiopterin would cause phenylalanine to be converted to phenyl ketones rather than to tyrosine.

questions.text: An infant of 9 months old was brought to the hospital for acute diarrhea, vomiting, With a “cabbage”-like smell, and failure to thrive. On examination, hepatomegaly was reported. Lab tests revealed more than normal tyrosine levels. These findings are due to a defect in the metabolism of an amino acid whose catabolic end products are:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fumarate and acetoacetate T his patient is suffering from Hereditary tyrosinemia type I (Hepatorenal tyrosinemia) that occurs due to a deficiency of the enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase (fumarylacetoacetase). Remember the enzyme deficiency - fumarylacetoacetase. That will help you to remember the end products – Fumarate and acetoacetate. Phenylalanine is first converted to tyrosine (For Subsequent metabolism of phenylalanine and tyrosine See fig. below Phenylalanine & tyrosine are both glucogenic and ketogenic . Fumarate is glucogenic while acetoacetate is ketogenic.

questions.text: The catecholamines such as Epinephrine and Nor-epinephrine are important bioamines and are required for the body to adapt to a great variety of acute and chronic stresses. The biosynthesis of Epinephrine from Norepinephrine requires which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

S-adenosyl methionine SAM (s-adenosyl methionine) is the methyl donor for the conversion of Norepinephrine to Epinephrine.

questions.text: The drug nitisinone is prescribed for the treatment of Alkaptonuria and Tyrosinemia. The use of Nitisinone can be best described as an example of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Substrate reduction therapy Nitisinone is prescribed for infantile tyrosinemia because it decreases the production of the substrate (fumarylacetoacetate) for the hydrolase, thus decreasing the velocity of the reaction and preventing substrate accumulation or in other causing substrate reduction for this enzyme Nitisinone is also used for the treatment of Alkaptonuria.

questions.text: Glycine can be synthesized from all except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Leucine

Extraedge:

Glycine can also be synthesized from choline through betaine and sarcosine as intermediates in the pathway.

questions.text: Biosynthesis of glycine takes place by various routes using a variety of precursors. Which of the following will give rise to glycine by transamination?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glyoxylate

questions.text: Catecholamines are involved in causing physiological changes to prepare the body for physical activity. Important catecholamines epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine are synthesized from L-DOPA as a precursor. Rate limiting step in catecholamine biosynthesis is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tyrosine hydroxylase

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of Phenylketonuria?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mental retardation Phenylketonuria: - Phenylketonuria (PKU) is the most common metabolic disorder in amino acid metabolism and causes the accumulation of phenylalanine in tissues and blood, and results in its increased excretion in urine. Phenylacetate gives the urine a mousy odor. Accumulation of phenylalanine in the brain impairs the transport and metabolism of other aromatic amino acids (tryptophan and tyrosine) leading to Mental retardation , failure to walk or talk, failure of growth, seizures, and tremors ret the characteristic findings in PKU. If untreated, the patients how very low IQs (below 50). Accumulation of phenylalanine competitively inhibits tyrosinase and impairs melanin formation. The result is hypopigmentation that causes light skin colour, fair hair, blue eyes, etc.

questions.text: Arrange the steps of the formation of creatinine from glycine in sequence: A. Transport of creatine from the liver to muscle via blood B. Formation of guanidino acetic acid from arginine and glycine C. Formation of creatine by methyl transferase D. Formation of creatine phosphate E. Conversion of creatine phosphate to creatinine Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

B→ C→A→ D → E

questions.text: A 50-year-old man who had experienced refractory hypertension for two years and sporadic panic attacks presented to the clinic complaining of a sudden attack of a throbbing headache. There was a lot of perspiration. He'd experienced attacks like it before. There is a history of hypertension in the family. Upon assessment, the patient's blood pressure was 170/90 mm Hg and her heart rate was 72/min. He was taking beta blockers. The results of the other tests were normal. The physician suspects pheochromocytoma which can be confirmed by testing levels of which of the following in his urine?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

VMA Pheochromocytoma - tumor for the Adrenal gland which secretes high amounts of epinephrine & Nor-epinephrine catabolic products of catecholamine - VMA VMA can be measured in 24 hours urine sample Clinical features are varied, but the classic triad symptoms is episodes of palpitations, headaches, and profuse sweating. Both benign and malignant pheochromocytomas can recur (after surgery) and hence long-term follow-up is important. The recurrence rate is also 10%.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true/false about phenylketonuria? A. Severe mental retardation at birth due to excess Phenylalanine B. Autosomal recessive C. Occurs due to overactivity of phenylalanine hydroxylase D. Prenatal diagnosis is not possible E. Limiting the substrate (phenylalanine) is first-line therapy Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.correct_answer: A. A-F, B-T, C-F, D-F, E-T
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A-F, B-T, C-F, D-F, E-T Most inborn errors of metabolism are Autosomal Recessive (AR). Phenyl ketonuria (PKU) is also an autosomal recessive disorder. [Option B] In phenylketonuria, there is the absence of the enzyme Phenylalanine Hydroxylase. This enzyme converts phenylalanine to tyrosine. As a result, there is an accumulation of phenylalanine in the blood and tyrosine becomes essential. Severe mental retardation occurs due to excess phenylalanine but the child is normal at birth as no problem during fetal development because the maternal enzyme breaks down phenylalanine. [Option A and C] Prenatal diagnosis is also possible [Option D] First-line therapy in Phenylketonuria & in most metabolic disorders is reducing the substrate. In PKU, this is phenylalanine. The target is to keep phenylalanine levels low enough to prevent mental retardation but should be enough for optimal growth [Option E]

questions.text: Which is not a biological derivative of tyrosine?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Melatonin Uses of tyrosine: ⇒Melatonin is formed from tryptophan, not from tyrosine Tip to remember: Tyrosine (smaller name) → Melanin (smaller name) Tryptophan (bigger name) → Melatonin (bigger name) Extra information: Phenylalanine is converted to tyrosine by the enzyme Phenylalanine Hydroxylase. Therefore, tyrosine is non-essential as it can be synthesized in the body from phenylalanine. Other uses of tryptophan are- Synthesis of vitamin B3 and serotonin

questions.text: A pediatrician examined a child and noted a musty odor in the baby’s wet diaper. A drop of her blood was obtained from a heel prick and used to perform a Guthrie bacterial inhibition assay. This test will detect the presence of which of the following in her blood?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Guthrie’s bacterial inhibition test: Screening test for phenylketonuria (PKU) Used to detect the abnormal presence of phenylalanine metabolites in blood i.e. Phenyl pyruvate Phenylalanine Phenyl lactate . Procedure: A small amount of blood sample is taken from the heel of the infant and placed in a medium with a strain of Bacillus subtilis , a bacteria that cannot grow without phenylalanine. If phenylalanine metabolites are present , then these bacteria reproduce , and the test result is positive, indicating that the patient has PKU .

Extraedge:

Other Diagnostic test for phenylketonuria is the ferric chloride test. This is a screening test in urine samples for phenyl ketones and hence gives a positive result for phenylpyruvate It is also positive for: Tyrosinemia MSUD Alkaptonuria

questions.text: Phenylalanine can be converted to tyrosine by hydroxylation by the enzyme PAH. The difference in molecular weight created by this conversion is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

16 Usually, students tend to mark 17 as the answer. Phenylalanine gets converted to Tyrosine by the enzyme Phenylalanine Hydroxylase. Most Hydroxylases are Mono-oxygenases i.e. EC No. 1. In hydroxylation reactions, only one oxygen atom from the molecular oxygen is added because H was already present in the phenylalanine. So, the change in molecular weight is by 16 and NOT 17 . Extra Information: Phenylalanine is an essential amino acid and its only role in the body is to give rise to tyrosine.

questions.text: Albinism is a hereditary disorder. In humans, it is manifested as partial or complete loss of melanin pigment in the skin, eyes, and hair. Albinism is a recessive autosomal trait. It is mainly two types: ocular and Oculocutaneous. The absence of melanin in the skin renders it susceptible to sunburn and skin cancer conditions. Select the incorrect statements about Albinism?

options.label: A
options.text: Deficiency of tyrosinase enzyme that causes melanin deficiency in the skin

options.label: B
options.text: Deficiency of tyrosine hydroxylase in the body resulting in melanin deficiency in the skin

options.label: C
options.text: Hypopigmentation of the ocular fundus and red or grey pigmentation in the iris. There is nystagmus, photophobia, and reduced visual acuity

options.label: D
options.text: Hypopigmentation in skin. Hypersensitivity to UV rays. High predisposition to naevi and melanomas. white

questions.correct_answer: B. Deficiency of tyrosine hydroxylase in the body resulting in melanin deficiency in the skin
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Deficiency of tyrosine hydroxylase in the body resulting in melanin deficiency in the skin Deficiency of tyrosine hydroxylase in the body results in three types of disorders that vary in severity. The mild type of disorder is characterized by an abnormal gait, poor coordination upon walking, and involuntary movements of the arms and legs. The condition is called dopa-responsive dystonia.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option: A. The deficiency of tyrosinase enzyme A is due to a mutation in the tyrosinase gene. It results in impaired melanin production in the skin together with other associated manifestations. Option: C. There is hypopigmentation of the ocular fundus and red or grey pigmentation in the iris There is nystagmus, photophobia, and reduced visual acuity. These features are seen in Oculocutaneous albinism involving skin, eyes, and hair. Option: D. There is hypopigmentation in the skin due to the partial or complete absence of melanin in the skin. skin is hypersensitive to UV rays and there is the high predisposition to naevi and melanomas. white.

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby girl was taken to a pediatrician after her parents observed black spots in her diaper after urination by the child. The pediatrician, told them this disorder can later lead to arthritis in the spine and large joints. This inborn error in the metabolism is due to a deficiency of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Homogentisate oxidase The diagnosis of this disorder is Alkaptonuria. Alkaptonuria: Defect in the catabolism of Tyrosine and Phenylalanine. Enzyme deficient is Homogentisate Dioxygenase ( new name ) or Homogentisate oxidase (old name) Note: If both names are given mark Homogentisate Dioxygenase. Urine turns black on exposure to air due to oxidation of homogentisic acid. Homogentisic acid is an intermediate in the catabolism of Tyrosine. Dark staining of diapers Deposition of black pigments (polymerization of homogentisic acid occurring in the body over years) in joints, cartilage, and collagenous tissue, known as ochronosis.

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option: A. Phosphofructokinase - RLE enzyme of glycolysis. Option: B. HMG CoA reductase - RLE enzyme of cholesterol synthesis Option: C. Xanthine oxidase - Rate limiting enzyme of purine catabolism

questions.text: Primary hyperoxaluria is a rare hereditary disorder affecting glycine metabolism. It is characterized by the repeated formation of stones in the kidneys and bladder. The disorder ends in end-stage renal disease, a life-threatening condition. There are high levels of oxalate in plasma that is excreted in high concentrations in urine. Oxalate combines with calcium and is deposited as calcium oxalate crystals in the kidneys. The condition can manifest as systemic oxalosis. Select the incorrect statement?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above

Random:

Explaination for incorrect options:- Option: A. Glycine transaminase catalyzes the reversible conversion of glyoxylate and glutamate into glycine and oxoglutarate into body tissues Option: B. In the body tissues, glyoxylate is accumulated. It is not converted into glycolate. Under normal conditions, part of glyoxylate is converted into glycine, and part of it is excreted in urine as glycolate. Option: C. Mutation in the GRHPR gene is responsible for the deficiency of glyoxylate reductase enzyme in the human body. This enzyme plays a role in preventing the buildup of a potentially harmful substance called glyoxylate by converting it to a substance called glycolate.
